name: Methohexital (Brevital)
summary: An ultra–short-acting barbiturate used for anesthesia induction and procedural sedation, with occasional historical use in psychiatric procedures such as electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).
description: Methohexital is a barbiturate with ultra–short duration of action, primarily used for induction of anesthesia and procedural sedation. In psychiatry, it has been used in the past as an anesthetic agent during electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) due to its rapid onset and recovery profile. It acts by enhancing GABA-A receptor activity, producing CNS depression.

sections.text: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, increasing chloride ion influx, hyperpolarizing neurons, and producing CNS depression.

sections.hepatic_impairment: Use with caution; may prolong recovery
sections.renal_impairment: No major adjustment, but use with caution

items: Powder for injection: reconstituted to 10 mg/mL or 50 mg/mL

other: Requires administration by trained personnel with resuscitation equipment available
Rapid injection increases risk of apnea

items: Blood pressure and ECG during procedure

sections.pregnancy: Category B; use only if clearly needed
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; avoid or use caution
sections.pediatrics: Safe with appropriate dosing for induction
sections.geriatrics: May require reduced dose due to increased sensitivity

sections.text: Not applicable—used for single-dose anesthesia or procedural sedation.

items: Favored for ECT due to rapid recovery profile
Replaced by propofol in many settings but still used for certain ECT protocols

seo.title: Methohexital (Brevital): Anesthetic for ECT and Procedural Sedation
seo.description: Methohexital (Brevital) is a short-acting barbiturate used for anesthesia induction, procedural sedation, and ECT.
